subject: RE: [junit] How can I automatize a mouse click ?
msgSnippet: ... Move the error message code into a factory method that you can override, for example: public class SomeClass { public void doSomething() { if(!ok) {
messageBody:
Waldomiro said:

> I have an unit of code which show a message when any error happens.
> Then the user needs to click ok to make the message disapears.
> I'd like to automatize the click, so the user doesn't need to
> be there when JUnit is testing my application.
> Is there anyway to do that ?

Move the error message code into a factory method that you can override, for
example:

public class SomeClass
{
public void doSomething()
{
if(!ok) { JOptionPane.showMessageDialog(...); }
}
}

To:

public class SomeClass
{
public void doSomething()
{
if(!ok) { showWarning(); }
}
protected void showWarning()
{
JOptionPane.showMessageDialog(...);
}
}

Then within your test code:

public void testDoSomething()
{
boolean [] warningShown[0] = { false };
// override your message
SomeClass c = new SomeClass()
{
protected void showWarning()
{
warningShown[0] = true;
}
}
// perform the work you want to test...
c.doSomething();
// check it
assertTrue(warningShown[0]);
}

I do similar things to this within some edit controls I've written. In real
life I want them to beep when something is wrong, in testing I don't.

Jonathan
